importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The AWS outage occurred on October 20, 2025, at approximately 07:11 GMT, marking the start of a widespread disruption that affected global digital services.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The outage lasted from 07:11 to 10:11 GMT, during which AWS services were disrupted, and 113 services were affected before restoration.

keyTakeAways: An error in a technical update to DynamoDB's API caused a cascading failure in AWS's Domain Name System (DNS), preventing apps from connecting to critical database services.
The outage originated in AWS's Virginia data center, which is one of its oldest and largest facilities.

The failure impacted 113 AWS services, including major platforms such as Snapchat, Pinterest, Apple TV, WhatsApp, Zoom, Roblox, Fortnite, Starbucks, Duolingo, Canva, and financial apps like Venmo and Coinbase.
The root cause was human error during a software update, not a cyberattack or intentional malicious activity.
Cloud outages are common but increasingly noticeable due to the critical dependence of modern digital infrastructure on cloud services like AWS.
AWS has a dominant market share of approximately 30% in the global cloud computing market, meaning its outages have a broad impact on businesses and consumers worldwide.
AWS acknowledged the issue, deployed multiple recovery paths, and stated that the main issue was resolved, though some users experienced delays in service restoration.

namedEntities.name: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The world's largest cloud computing service provider, offering infrastructure as a service to millions of businesses and applications.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: AWS is the central infrastructure provider whose outage disrupted thousands of online services, demonstrating how interconnected modern digital systems are and how vulnerable they can be to single-point failures in cloud infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: DynamoDB
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A key cloud database service used by AWS to store user data and other critical information for online platforms.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The technical update to DynamoDB’s API caused a DNS failure, which in turn led to a cascading failure across multiple AWS services and affected numerous apps dependent on it.

namedEntities.name: Domain Name System (DNS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The internet's phone book that translates website names into IP addresses for computers to connect to servers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A malfunction in DNS due to the API update prevented apps from finding server addresses, directly leading to the loss of connectivity for critical services.

namedEntities.name: Virginia (AWS data center)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: One of AWS’s oldest and largest data centers located in Virginia, where the initial outage originated.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The failure began in this key data center, highlighting the critical role of physical infrastructure locations in cloud reliability and failure propagation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: An AWS outage originating in Virginia’s primary data center due to a flawed software update to DynamoDB’s API caused a DNS failure that disrupted access to 113 services, including major apps like Snapchat, WhatsApp, Roblox, and financial platforms such as Venmo and Coinbase. The outage affected global services across communication, entertainment, finance, and smart home devices, revealing the deep dependence of modern digital life on cloud infrastructure. Experts concluded the incident was the result of human error, not a cyberattack, and underscored AWS’s dominant market position and the systemic fragility of digital ecosystems when reliant on a single provider.
title: What caused Amazon’s AWS outage, and why did so many major apps go offline?
